item.title: Our New Operatories
item.description:
Patients are really enjoying our new operatories.  (A dental operatory is the room where you sit and get your dentistry done, not where you get your appendix out.)  Our new chairs are dangerous during lunchtime.  They are so comfortable, if we sit in them to take a break, the rest of the day is shot.

Tags: 
dental office
technology
item.dc:creator: Dr. Inge

item.title: Truly a Love/Hate Relationship
item.description:
How many times have we heard that expression? And most of the time it is connected with computers, iPhones, and other high-tech toys. The digital age has been with us for a long time now. Most people who are not of the boomer generation don't even recall a time you actually had to find a phone booth if you needed to make a call away from home.

It constantly amazes me that there actually are people out there who know what's going on with modern technology. But they don't call them "computer nerds" for nothing. (Just kidding. Actually some of my best friends are computer nerds.)

Just like most of the other professions, modern dentistry has become totally immersed in developing technologies. We take digital x-rays and photos. We take digital impressions for crowns, bridges, and dentures. We send in electronic dental claims. We have appointment reminders by smart phone, email, or social media. Almost every dentist has its office website and Facebook page. We can actually make one appointment crowns milled in by a scanned in impression. Implants are milled in with electronic scanning. We use several types of lasers. And on and on.

Our philosophy at Inge Dental is to be just a half step behind the cutting edge of dental technology. In spite of the impressiveness of the bells and whistles of the newest and latest, the fact remains that not everything works. This may be ok in a laboratory commercial setting, but with our patients, well, we don't want them to be Ginny Pigs. So we hang back until we know most of the bugs are out, and we can trust the technology to truly serve our patients and not hurt them.

Tags: 
technology
item.dc:creator: Dr. Inge
